original_data.question: A 74-year-old man was admitted to the intensive care ward due to progressive dyspnea, cough with pink sputum, and diaphoresis. He had 2 myocardial infarctions at the age of 66 and 69 years and suffers from chronic heart failure. At the time of presentation, his vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg, heart rate 108/min, respiratory rate 29/min, and temperature 35.5°C (95.9°F). On physical examination, the patient sits upright. He is lethargic and cyanotic. Lung auscultation reveals widespread bilateral fine rales. Cardiac examination is significant for S3, accentuation of the pulmonic component of S2, and a systolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart. Soon after hospitalization, the patient develops ventricular fibrillation and dies despite adequate resuscitation measures. Which microscopic finding would you expect to see in this patient on autopsy?

options.A: Brownish inclusions in the pulmonary macrophages on H&E staining
options.B: Positive Prussian-blue staining of the kidney tissue
options.D: Positive Congo-red staining of the cardiac tissue

model_response:
The clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary edema secondary to acute myocardial infarction. The autopsy findings of brownish inclusions in the pulmonary macrophages on H&E staining are suggestive of hemosiderin. The hemosiderin is taken up by pulmonary macrophages and stored as hemosiderin granules. The hemosiderin pigment is composed of ferritin complexes and can be visualized by the Prussian-blue staining. The accumulation of hemosiderin in the tissues is known as hemosiderosis. The hemosiderin accumulation in the heart can be seen by the positive Congo-red staining. The ground-glass hepatocytes are seen in the setting of chronic hepatitis B infection.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
**Description:**The patient has been admitted to a care facility and their community medications are suspended until hospital discharge.

Advanced and highly specialized care provided to medical or surgical patients whose conditions are life-threatening and require comprehensive care and constant monitoring. It is usually administered in specially equipped units of a health care facility.
Advancing in extent or severity.
Difficult or labored breathing.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.
Material coughed up from the lungs and expectorated via the mouth. It contains MUCUS, cellular debris, and microorganisms. It may also contain blood or pus.
Profuse sweating.
The muscle tissue of the HEART. It is composed of striated, involuntary muscle cells (MYOCYTES, CARDIAC) connected to form the contractile pump to generate blood flow.
Formation of an infarct, which is NECROSIS in tissue due to local ISCHEMIA resulting from obstruction of BLOOD CIRCULATION, most commonly by a THROMBUS or EMBOLUS.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
State of severe distress associated with events that threaten the intactness of the person, can be physical, mental, or emotional.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Characterized by a lack of vitality or energy.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Abnormal breath sounds (crackles) heard on auscultation, indicating inflammation, fluid, or infection of the lung.
A physical examination focusing on areas of interest other than the heart.
The third heart sound (S3) is related to rapid filling in diastole. S3 can be a normal finding in children and adolescents but suggests heart failure in older patients. []
A protein cleavage product with a demonstrated function.
Period of contraction of the HEART, especially of the HEART VENTRICLES.
DNA-(apurinic or apyrimidinic site) lyase (318 aa, ~36 kDa) is encoded by the human APEX1 gene. This protein plays a role in both DNA repair and the regulation of transcription.
The hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood.
The confinement of a patient in a hospital.

A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia that is characterized by uncoordinated extremely rapid firing of electrical impulses (400-600/min) in HEART VENTRICLES. Such asynchronous ventricular quivering or fibrillation prevents any effective cardiac output and results in unconsciousness (SYNCOPE). It is one of the major electrocardiographic patterns seen with CARDIAC ARREST.
Meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement; enough to meet the needs of a situation.
The restoration to life or consciousness of one apparently dead. (Dorland, 27th ed)
Too small to be seen except under a microscope.
Clinical manifestations that can be either objective when observed by a physician, or subjective when perceived by the patient.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Postmortem examination of the body.
